headline: Salted Caramel Chocolate Pecan Cookies
description: These chocolate pecan cookies are shortbread-style thumbprint confections coated in pecans, filled with salted caramel, and drizzled with chocolate.

video.description: Divine salted caramel and chocolate over shortbread cookies!
video.name: Salted Caramel-Chocolate-Pecan Cookies

name: Salted Caramel Chocolate Pecan Cookies

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line 3 to 4 baking sheets with parchment paper.

Beat butter and sugar together in a bowl using an electric mixer until pale and fluffy. Beat in vanilla extract. Reduce mixer speed to low and gradually beat in flour and 1/2 teaspoon salt. Press dough together in plastic wrap; roll dough into 1 1/2-inch balls.

Place beaten eggs in one small dish and pecans in another dish. Dip each dough ball into the eggs and roll in pecans. Place dredged balls on the prepared baking sheets; press your thumb into the center of each ball.
Bake in the preheated oven for 10 minutes. Press each cookie again, with a spoon. Return to the oven and continue baking until golden, about 10 minutes more. Cool on wire racks.

Combine caramels and heavy cream in a small saucepan over low heat. Cook, stirring constantly, until caramels are melted and mixture is smooth, 4 to 6 minutes. Spoon the mixture into the thumbprints of the cookies and sprinkle with sea salt.
Melt chocolate chips in a microwave-safe bowl in 15-second intervals, stirring after each melting, 1 to 3 minutes. Stir in oil. Drizzle chocolate over the cookies.

review.reviewBody: Great concept- but it does not work. I followed the directions to the letter. It never formed a dough- it was a crumbly mess. I didn't want to waste ingredients- so I pressed each spoonful into a ball and carefully put a indentation in. Once you get to this point- chocolate and caramel can cover anything- BUT the dough portion does not work.

Delicious! A crowd favorite! Three adjustments needed. 1. Like the other reviewers, I added 1/2 cup less flour. 2. AND...the recipe listed is incorrect. It says to add half the amount of butter than it shows in the video. At first I followed the recipe and the flour was a crumbly mess. I then watched the video and saw they added twice as much butter. I added it to my dry flour mixture and it turned out perfectly. 3. Thankfully, I added about 1 teaspoon rather than a tablespoon of oil to the chocolate because it made the chocolate too thin to dry. Next time I won't add the oil. I don't think it's necessary.

I made six types of cookies for a school staff, and this was by far the most popular of all. I did make one change: I used three cups of finely chopped pecans to roll the cookies in. These will be added to my regular cookie rotation! Thanks so much for this delicious recipe!
My Xmas cookie exchange people loved these. It was 2 yrs ago. Thinking of making them again , they were a big hit.

I made these last Christmas as an edition to our traditional cookies we have made for over 50 years. They were a hit and requested again for this year. I followed the directions exactly and had no problems. They will become a permanent addition to our family tradition. My sister and I do at least 40 cans and plates for family and friends.
These were delicious with and without the caramel & chocolate. I will definitely be making again.

The cookies were very dry and crumbly. Suggestion: cut back on flour. Iâ€™m a home baker of several decades and have a lot of experience baking. They are definitely one to make again, but will hold off on the last 1/2 cup of flour and do a test bake before continuing.
These cookies are outrageous! Everyone loved them and they make a very impressive presentation, too.

They were good but had a heavy flour taste. I had about a little over 1 cup of batter crumbles left in bottom of mixing bowl that would not form a ball. After I scooped out batter & attempted roll into a ball they just crumbled into pieces. So, instead I squeezed them into a ball shape. Next time will DEFINITELY CUT BACK ON THE FLOUR. In addition I used 3x more nuts to roll the batter in
Followed recipe. Every time I tried to press into the center the cookies fell apart. Will not try to make them again and would not recommend.

Time consuming for sure. I made the dough and rolled into balls but couldn't bake until the next day. Won't do that again, I'll allow more time when starting these. Had to wait until dough softened to put a thumb print in them. The taste was fine, but I think next time I'd use almond extract instead of vanilla for a little more flavor.
Absolutely delicious! Well worth the extra time and effort.

Oh, my goodness! These are delicious, but so much work. Took me over 3 hours, start to finish. Next time, I wonâ€™t add the oil to the chocolate-it didnâ€™t want to set up. The only change I made was to add 2 Tbsp of milk to the dough, on another reviewerâ€™s suggestion, because it was too crumbly. Thanks for a great recipe!
I love these!! I did use twice the pecans and 1 less egg mixed with about 1/4 cup of water. I also forgot the salt, but since there is salt on the caramel it didnâ€™t seem to make a difference.

Made these for the neighbors for Christmas and got rave reviews and one recipe request. 
Next time I would add a little less flour; more nuts; one bag of 36 caramels is plenty and I used my 1 1/2" cookie scoop and I got about 30 cookies.
Delicious! Family loved these. Next time I will make them smaller. Also, I needed double the amount of nuts!
These were a big hit at my holiday party but they are delicate so be careful while transporting them
Helps to watch the video to see how the spoon is used to create a larger thumbprint for the caramel.
very very yum!! The cookie dough was a big dry and crumbly so i added some milk to the dough and mixed it up again. I would definitely make these again as they hit the spot!

I'm not usually much of a shortbread cookie fan, but this recipe is delicious! It stays together better than most shortbread recipes. Be sure to be a bit aggressive when making the indentationâ€” my only complaint was that my indentations didn't hold, so the caramel spilled over.

I love shortbread style cookles and these may be the most delicious cookie I have ever tasted! However..... 1) it doesn't take much salt to give the yummy salted caramel flavor, 2) double or triple the finely chopped pecans, and 3) THIS IS A LOT OF WORK! Worth it but a 2-3 hour project!
These cookies are good, but do require some work. As such, I will probably only make for special occasions...which will make them all the more special when I do.
Amazing!
Theyâ€™re fantastic! A bit of time is invested to make these but theyâ€™re worth the effort. Great for special occasions! A real crowd pleaser

Recipe was followed as written. They turned out just like the photo but my family and I rated them just â€˜okâ€™. I donâ€™t think this is the fault of the recipe, I think we just donâ€™t enjoy the dry shortbread type cookie. I knew that going in, but thought the caramel would save them.

Brought this to a potluck we had at work. Was a big hit. Got a few Skype messages, emails, etc, from other staff members saying how great they were and asking if I can share the recipe! 
The only issue I had is that, I think the receipe say it would make 48 cookies? No way, I made the ball relatively small (maybe one inch) and I probably ended up with somewhwere between 32 and 36 cookies (didn't actually count). I had a couple myself and I love them. Definitely will make again!
Not sure of these, but I make similar ones at Christmas every year and they are absolutely my fave. I call them Turtle Thumbprints though and the cookie is chocolate, not shortbread.
Amazing cookies! Takes some time to roll each one but so worth it!

These were pretty darn good. The only issues I had, were they seemed to have a heavy flour taste and I didn't have near enough pecans. I think I will cut the flour down next time I make these (and, trust me, there will be a next time!). Re-reading this recipe before I reviewed it, I realized I forgot to add in the oil to the chocolate chips. Didn't even miss it, so, not sure if it is really necessary. This is a keeper for sure!

This is my first ever recipe review, and I took a chance on a new recipe with no reviews. I was not disappointed at all. These cookies are very easy to make and they turned out exactly as pictured. This is a firm shortbread pecan sandy type cookie. I halved the recipe and added about 2 Tbsp of flour due to high altitude but I'm not sure it was necessary...mostly it's out of habit. I also had leftover prepared caramel for apple dipping so I substituted that for the caramels and cream. Taste was great, but I'm betting the real caramels and cream are even better. I also baked these on parchment for easy clean up. Thanks for posting... I look forward to making more!

There are a couple of things that should be clarified in the recipe: butter should be softened. And press with a spoon after they come out of the oven cause obviously they will be hot to touch. Overall the process wasnâ€™t too bad. They came out really good and Iâ€™m not a huge sweets fan. Nor do I really love caramel, but I am making these for someone else. My 11 year old loved them. I did half pecan rolled and half almond rolled, because I thought I had enough pecans. Wrong. Oh well. Both came out very good. Recommend drizzling the chocolate with a fork. I tried a spoon and got globs. #notabaker
